intro: Acacia mutabilis subsp. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf wattle, is a shrub native to southern Australia. It is characterized by its feathery, bipinnate leaves that are narrow and often grayish-green in color. The plant produces yellow flowers in late spring to early summer, which are clustered in cylindrical spikes. It thrives in well-drained soils and is drought-tolerant, making it suitable for arid and semi-arid environments. The species is also valued for its ornamental appeal and ability to fix nitrogen, benefiting surrounding vegetation.

This subspecies is commonly found in arid and semi-arid regions within these states. It thrives in sandy soils and is often seen along roadsides and in open woodlands. The plant is well adapted to the harsh climate of these areas. Its distribution is largely confined to the southern and western parts of Australia.
